div.head: Sample
div.p: The sample chosen for test was a lonsdaleite+diamond standard coming from the collections of the Muséum National d'Histoire Naturelle in Paris (Fig. 1). The unusual lonsdaleite and diamond association, typical of ultrahigh stress and pressure conditions, was produced during a meteorite impact, in southern Urals..

div.head: Experiments
div.p: Experiments were performed using the ID13 microgoniometer at 100 K with a 5 micron beam at λ=0.095

nm. An image of the sample-flake glued to a glass capillary is shown in Fig. 1 A 10x10 µm 2 mesh-scan was performed with an angular rotation of 1 0 at every mesh-point. 2D-patterns of 1 sec each were collected with a MARCCD. A sample area of 0.5x0.6 mm 2 was scanned.

div.head: Results
div.p: Fig. 2 As the test provided promising results, even with the small size of the sample, we will request to be able to continue, by performing the same procedure on Norway and Kazakhstan samples. 10x10µm 2 Fig.2 Composite image of mesh-scan. Selected patterns are shown enlarged to the right.

figure.figDesc: Names and affiliations of applicants (* indicates experimentalists): Dr. G. Godard*: Institute de Physique du Globe de Paris, CNRS UMR Dr. P. Philippot: Geosciences Marines, CNRS-IPGP, Universite Paris-Jussieu Prof. D. Smith Museum National d'Histoire naturelle, 61, rue Buffon; 75005

Fig.2 shows a composite "image" of the scanned zone. The image-pixels correspond to high resolution patterns. Selected patterns shwon to the right reveal the presence of various phases. Detailed analysis of the phases is in progress. We shall present the preliminary results at the 7 th International Eclogite Conference of Seggau, in July 2005 (G. Godard, D. Smith, L. Dobrzhinetskaya, C. Riekel, & M. Belleil [2005].-Why is diamond from UHPM rocks disordered? Investigation by raman spectroscopy and synchrotron X-ray microdiffraction. IEC-7, 2005 Seggau, Austria).

figure.head: Fig. 1 Fig. 2
figure.figDesc: Fig.1 Microscopy image of sample recorded with the on-axis microscope of the microgoniometer. The green bar corresponds to 50 µm.Fig.1 Microscopy image of sample recorded with the on-axis microscope of the microgoniometer. The green bar corresponds to 50 µm.

figure.head: Fig. 2
figure.figDesc: Fig.2 Composite image of mesh-scan. Selected patterns are shown enlarged to the right.

div.p: Experiment title: X-ray tomography and microdiffraction of diamond and londsaleite bearing microinclusions in natural ultrahigh pressure metamorphic rocks
